Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 06/13/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at Samantha Way 517-243-9743.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4111 Job description
(1) An institution shall provide a job description for each
staff position that identifies rules, required
qualifications, and lines of authority.
Two out of thirty-eight new hire files were missing job descriptions.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of
all of the following information prior to employment
or at the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained
prior to employment from persons unrelated to
the employee and which are less than 12
months old.
Six out of thirty-eight new hire files did not have three dated references obtained
prior to employment from persons unrelated to the employee.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Interim, CAP Approved 7/20/2023
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for

performance within 30 days of the completion of
the probationary period or within 180 days,
whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 4 substantiated incidents of maltreatment since the last inspection, but
three were prior to the provisional license being issued and one resulted in the
provisional recommendation. There have been no substantiated incidents since
the provisional license issuance.
➢ Investigation report 2023C0000484SI dated 08/07/2023 which found the
facility in non-complaince of a staff member engaging in an inappropriate
relationship with a youth. A corrective action plan dated 08/29/2023 was
approved that included the staff member involved being terminated and
implementation of training staff on identifing inappropraite behavior of
peers/staff.
➢ Investigation report 2023C0000650SI dated 08/22/2023 which found the
facility in non-complaince of a staff member punching a youth. A CAP dated
09/15/2023 was approved and included the staff member involved being
terminated and implementation of retraining staff on professional
bounderies.
➢ Investigation report 2023C0000787SI dated 12/12/2023 which found the
facility in non-complaince of a staff member that threw a youth to the floor
and punched him after youth threw urine on staff, youth was not examined
by medical staff after being assualted by staff. Staff placed youth in
seclusion and did not follow seclusion procedures and facility was aware of
youth being bullied but failed to provide postive interventions to staff to
secure safety. A corrective action plan dated 01/29/2024 was approved that
included termination of the staff member involved, implementing a new
checklist for new employee for ongoing coaching and mentoring by
supervisors, updated seclusion policy/documentation and trained all staff,
all restaints and seclusions will be reviewed by supervisors and mangers to
ensure accuracy, and weekly team meetings will review treatment plans
and cover interventions to be used with individual youths.
➢ Investigation report 2024C0000854SI dated 12/07/2023 which found the
facility in non-compliance of staff members improperly restraining a youth
resulting in the youth sustaining a nosebleed, youth did not receive medical
care for the nosebleed, a restraint report was not completed, staff are
mandated reporters and they failed to complete a report after incident. A
corrective action plan dated 01/12/2024 was approved that included staff
involved received verbal consultation, managers and supervisors will be
coaching and mentor staff through safe and appropriate restraints,
documentation and restraints debriefing forms will be reviewed to ensure
accuracy, management team will review documentation and video footage
during team meetings, all staff will be trained on policy for documenting
incident report, mandate reporting, and restraints. Mandate reporter
procedures were placed in staff common areas.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The facility has submitted 13 acceptable corrective action plans (CAPS) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
review period begins June 9, 2023, until current. The Agency was granted a 1st
Provisional License on February 02, 2024, due to Special Investigation Report
2023C0000787. Prior to Provisional License being granted, there were two
investigations that resulted in a CAP which were due to supervision, improper
restraints, not documenting seclusion incident report documentation, and not
obtaining medical care after a youth is restrained.
Since the start of the 1st Provisional License on February 2, 2024, there have been
five investigations, 1 resulting in compliance, and three are pending investigations.
The 4 pending investigations:
➢ 2024SIC0001352 Youth was assaulted by another resident, reported
the assault to staff and has not been kept safe.
➢ 2024SIC0001483 On an unknown date while youth was at the facility, an
unknown staff member assaulted the youth. Youth was not injured, and
staff member was terminated.
➢ 2024SIC0001521 Youth was slammed against the wall by staff during
an escalated incident.
➢ 2024SIC0001559 A staff member left a door unsecured and youth were
able to make entry and cause a fight with othe youth.
➢
➢ The facility was placed on a 1st Provisional License due to staff punching, choking,
and pushing youth after youth threw urine at staff. The youth did not immediately
receive medical care after being assaulted by the staff. The agency did not provide
positive intervention strategies to staff to secure safety and provide individual
treatment to the youth that was being bullied. The facility has implemented and
complied with all their CAPs. They have been working on several active CAPs
from the prior period and have completed some of them during this period. Areas
of focus were proper restraint methods and use of verbal de-escalation, mandated
reporting requirements, maintaining ratio, staff supervision, and following facility
policies. To address these issues, numerous staff trainings have occurred,
meetings are structured to address the issues and provide oversight, the quality
assurance manager has been enlisted to provide additional oversight to various
areas, and the new Director has provided increased structure, reinstituted
programming, ensures follow through, and requires accountability. There is
notable improvement in oversight and accountability which has improved the
programming and decreased complaints, restraints, and seclusions. They took
appropriate steps by immediately putting staff involved on leave and terminating
after the investigations were completed. The facility has implemented coordinators
(experienced workers) on all the pods that provides mentoring and coaching to
direct care staff throughout their shift. The managers and supervisors hold weekly
meetings with direct care staff and they provide supervision, review incident
reports, provide training on any updated policy and procedures. The Chief

Administrator reported some mandatory overtime continues when needed, but with
the weekly job fairs there are no reported issues with maintaining ratio.
➢
➢ Since being under a First Provisional License the facility completed biweekly
onsite meetings with licensing consultant and complied with monthly unannounced
visits. The biweekly meetings started in September of 2023 and lasted until June
of 2024. During these meetings, DCWL met with RCTAU and leadership at the
facility. These meetings consisted of review of CAP compliance and provide
consultation and technical assistance as needed. Staff and Youths were
interviewed during these visits. Youths consistently reported increased activities
and use of the facility services, individual and group therapy, and positive
engagement with staff and administration. The facility has the student council
program for youths in which it provides an outlet for youths to express their
concerns.
➢
Financial Overview
The financial report and budget were reviewed and showed no concerns.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The agency is complaint with PREA.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was thorough and identified new processes
implemented into staff training such as a shadowing form for new employees that
helps with identifying employee strengths and areas of additional training.
Experienced staff (Coordinators) float the pods and provide support and mentor
direct care staff. Managers and Directors are watching live footage of all the pods
to ensure staff are providing appropriate care and supervision. The facility is
continually assessing methods to improve supporting existing and expanding
recruitment of new staff. The facility has weekly hiring fairs to ensure they have
sufficient staff. The Chief Administrator reported over the past six months there
has been a significate reduction in investigation and the risk stratification score has
decreased. The facility has hired a licensed beautician onsite to cut and style all
the youths hair. The facility has improved in their implementation of CAPS and
completed most of them from this period. The work and completion of these CAPS
appears to have made a direct positive impact on the program as evidenced by the
reduced number of investigations and violations in the past six months. They have
also actively participated with the Residential Collaboration and Technical
Assistance Unit (RCTAU), and that has been reported as a successful and
beneficial partnership by both the RCTAU staff and the facility administration.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported feeling very supported, participating in monthly training,
and feel the facility is meeting the needs of the youths. Youths interviewed
reported feeling safe, receiving individual and group therapy, getting enough food,

and all their needs are being met. Youths reported having positive relationships
with staff and expressed no concerns regarding the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on 06/14/2024
observed Pods, Gym, the youths' bedrooms, shower area, medication room,
control rooms, and classrooms. There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
